questions.question: What is the recommended time frame for urine specimen analysis to avoid significant changes?
questions.explanation: Urine should be examined within 2 hours to prevent bacterial growth and cell degradation.

questions.question: Which urinary cast is most indicative of glomerulonephritis?
questions.explanation: RBC casts signify bleeding from the glomeruli, characteristic of glomerulonephritis.

questions.question: What is the main constituent of urinary casts?
questions.explanation: Tamm-Horsfall protein secreted by tubular cells forms the matrix of casts.

questions.question: Which stain is used to detect fecal fat?
questions.explanation: Sudan III stain is used to identify neutral fat droplets in fecal specimens.

questions.question: What CSF cell type predominates in viral meningitis?
questions.explanation: Lymphocytic pleocytosis is typical in viral (aseptic) meningitis.

questions.question: What is a common finding in urine sediment of nephrotic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Fatty casts and oval fat bodies are characteristic findings in nephrotic syndrome.

questions.question: Which parasite is diagnosed through urine examination in endemic areas?
questions.explanation: Eggs of Schistosoma haematobium can be detected in urine samples.

questions.question: Which fluid has a milky appearance due to high triglycerides?
questions.explanation: Chylous fluids appear milky from lymphatic leakage rich in triglycerides.

questions.question: What is the expected normal sperm motility percentage in semen analysis?
questions.explanation: WHO criteria require at least 50% progressive motility for normal semen analysis.

questions.question: What is the effect of light on urine bilirubin measurement?
questions.explanation: Bilirubin is light-sensitive and degrades on exposure, lowering measured values.
